sions which used very frequently to take place between Scipio and me concerning friendship. And yet he indeed used to say that nothing was more difficult than for friend- ship to continue right up to the last day of life. For it often happened either that the same thing was not advantageous to both, or that the same opinion was not held concerning public affairs. He used often to say that man’s moral prin· ciple changed also, sometimes through adversity, sometimes through the increasing burden of age.
